description: From Middle English oratorie, from Anglo-Norman oratorie, Middle French oratoire, and their source, Late Latin ōrātōrium. Doublet of oratorio.

entries.meaning: A private chapel or prayer room. [from 14th c.]
A Roman Catholic chapel; a building for public or private worship that is not a parish church.
(specifically) A Catholic church belonging to the Oratory of Saint Philip Neri.

description: Borrowed from Latin ōrātōria, from the feminine of ōrātōrius (“oratorial”).

entries.meaning: The art of public speaking, especially in a formal, expressive, or forceful manner. [from 16th c.]
Eloquence; the quality of artistry and persuasiveness in speech or writing.
